isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 5000 9100 9200 9400 9900 MODELS BUILT OCTOBER 1, 1998 AND AFTER - GAUGES AND WARNING LIGHTS - 5000, 5000i, 9000, 9000i - PROGRAMMING - PULSES/MILES (SPEEDOMETER) DIP SWITCHES

svcprocinfo.para: With Electronic Engines- the 10 pulses/miles (speedometer) DIP switches are set at a one position, which programs the module to receive the serial data input signal. The axle ratio, tire revolutions per mile, the number of teeth on the transmission speedometer gear, etc. are programmed into the engine ECM and not the Speedometer/Tachometer module.

important.para: If tire size, axle ratios, etc. are changed, the ECM must be reprogrammed, not the Speedometer/Tachometer cluster.

svcprocinfo.para: Refer to GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL, Electronic Engine Controls, in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for additional information on reprogramming speedometer effects.

With Mechanical Engines - The 10 pulses/miles (speedometer) DIP switches are set based upon the revolutions per mile of the propeller shaft (same as transmission output shaft). Refer to Calculations for Selecting Speedometer Switch Settings for calculation and switch setting charts.
The DIP switches are located on the top edge of the Speedometer/Tachometer module and can be accessed by pulling the unit out of the instrument panel for manual programming.

svcsubproc.title: Calculations For Selecting Pulses/Miles (Speedometer) DIP Switch Settings
svcsubproc.para: The Speedometer/Tachometer module is programmed for an input signal reflecting the number of pulses per mile from the vehicle speed sensor. The chart in this section factors in the speedometer gear pulse information, but the number of revolutions per mile of the propeller shaft (same as the output shaft) must be calculated.
The calculation requires two numbers: the number of revolutions per mile for the vehicle tire size, and the rear axle ratio.
The tire revolutions per mile can be obtained from:

step1.para: Calculating the figure using the measured distance (in feet) that the truck travels in exactly one revolution of the wheels. 5280 divided by the measured distance = tire revolutions per mile.

svcsubproc.para: The axle ratio can be obtained from:

item.para: Axle data stamped on the differential carrier.
Counting the number (including fractions) of prop shaft revolutions for one tire revolution.

svcsubproc.para: Prop revolutions per mile = axle ratio multiplied by the tire revolutions per mile.
Tire Revs/Mile - 471 (12.00 R 20 tire) Axle Ratio - 3.70:1

Look this number up in Switch Setting Chart and use the switch settings in the column to the right of the prop rev/mile (1742 in the example) for the new switch positions ( Figure 10). The setting for the example would be 0001011100 shown in Figure 10.
